LOYOLA WINS PEACE CONTEST

Remarkable Ancient Greek Surgical Instruments to Come to Hopkins,
Says the London Times.

Jerome H. Joyce Winner of Oratorical
Contest and a Handsome Prize.
Georgetown Is Second.

The Times, London, England,
announces that a set of 37 remarkable ancient Greek surgical instruments, discovered near the site of
Kolophon, in India, have been
given to Johns Hopkins University
and will soon be brought to America.
They were for a considerable
time in the possession of the late
Alfred 0. Van Lannep, Dutch viceconsul at Smyrna, and have been
taken to England.
The 'instruments show a type of
workmanship unequaled in any
other specimens extant and generally reveal the very great progress in surgery which the ancients
had made.
Their date, though somewhat uncertain, was probably the first or
second century A. D. It is possible, however, that it may have
been before the Christian era.
With two exceptions, all the instruments are of bronze. The
blades were originally steel, but in
each case this metal has been almost completely destroyed by rust.

At the annual oratorical contest
under the auspices of the Maryland Peace Society, held in McCoy Hall last Friday evening, Jerome II. Joyce, the representative
of Loyola College of Baltimore,
was awarded the decision by the
judges, Rev. C. A. Rubenstein, Dr.
O. Edward Janney, Mr. W. H.
Morriss, Ex-Judge Alfred S. Niles
and Rev. Louis O'Donovan. The
Georgetown representative, Bernard
L. Brady, was announced as a close
second in the minds of the judges.
The winner was awarded a prize
of seventy-five dollars, and is also
entitled to the privilege of taking
part in the intercollegiate contest.
Brady, of Georgetown, who as
first speaker, told of "The Immediate Needs of the Peace Movement,” displayed the confidence and
force of a practiced orator. The
weak point of his highly polished
oration was a marked exaggeration in his frequent similies and
metaphors. He advanced, as his
view of the needs of the movement
for universal peace, a ,highly developed international conference, a

(Continued on page 3, col. 2)

competent international court with
supreme power in all cases of international disputes, and an unprejudiced court of inquiry, to
thrash out every possible difference
among the powers.
Joyce delivered his winning speech
next, and his strong, straightforward sentences, with just enough
of comparisons and illustrations to
make them clear, made evident his
skill in presenting complex ideas
in a clear manner. In discussing
the "Reasonableness of Peace," he
based his argument on the comparison of the rules of justice and
methods of settling disputes among
individuals with the methods employed among nations. He pictured
war as a bad means, no matter how
justifiable the end, with the single
exception of cases of self-defence.
The Hopkins man, Moses Baroway, spoke next. Being handicapped by an uneffective delivery,
his good points in regard to "Disillusionment" as to the professed
advantages of war, failed to make
a strong impression. The last
speaker, Orville M. Moore, of St.
John's College, though his ideas as
to a "Simple Method of Forwarding Universal Peace" were sound,
betrayed a lack of experience when
compared with the other orators.

Freshmen at Washington.

Of especial significance in the
light of our own plans for a code
of freshmen regulations comes the
announcement that the freshman
class at the University of Washington have, of their own free will,
resumed wearing their distinguishing green caps, and are refraining
from smoking on the campus—two
of the things required of them by
the upper classes before the faculty
did away with all forms of class
distinction.
The freshmen were free to glory
in their new-found emancipation
and unusually elevated position. Instead, however, they have stuck to
the traditions of their predecessors,
and administered what appears to
be a subtle rebuke to the powers
that be.
This is the spirit in which any
freshman regulations made by our
Studc,nt Council in the future should
be regarded. If physical force is
needed to make effective the rules,
they cease to be rules of conduct
and become merely a code pointing
out the actions for which an upperclass man may inflict verbal or
physical violence, according as he
is fitted naturally, upon a freshman.
If, on the other hand, they are
received by the University as rules
which will promote college and
class spirit, they will soon be deeprooted traditions. A freshman
should be as proud of his class as
the senior is of his, and should
have no shame in showing that he
is not an upperclass man. By be-

The Honor System.

The second set of examinations
to be held under the new honor system will begin Friday. Under the
system there will be no patrolling
of the rooms by the professors and
instructors. These men will be
present—if at all—only to answer
such questions as the perplexed examinee may wish to ask. They are
placing explicit confidence in all the
students, and all they expect in return is the signing of the little
pledge:
"I have neither received nor given
aid during this examination.
Signature."
Last December, a majority of the
students signed the pledge. The
small number who did not perhaps
overlooked the detail. This was
shown by the return of many who
had left the examination rooms to
"sign up" after they had handed
in their books.
The failure to sign was excused
last December. The system was
new and it could not be expected
to work without a flaw, but better
results are hoped for during this
and next week. Every professor in
the University is in favor of the
system, and all would like to see it
come into perfect working order
during the coming examinations.
To accomplish this success, it is
only necessary to remind yourself
before going into each exam that
the pledge should be signed and
then do it.

Dr. Ernest Elster, professor of
modern German philology and literature at the University of Marburg, will deliver a lecture in German on "Heine," next Wednesday
evening at 8.15 in McCoy Hall.
Dr. Elster was brought to this
country to give a brief course of
lectures at Cornell University, which
lasted until the past Friday. Leaving Ithaca, he struck through the
Middle West, where he is appearing at several universities before
coming to Hopkins. He will arrive
in Baltimore Wednesday morning,
and will spend the day at the Rennert. He will take luncheon with
Dr. and Mrs. Wood, who have invited the members of the Germanic
Seminary to meet their distinguished guest.
Dr. Elster was born in Frankfurt-on-Main, in 186o, and comes
from a family of well-known scholars. He received his secondary
education at such noted universities
as Berlin, Jena, and Leipzig, and
since his graduation has filled positions at Glasgow and Leipzig.
In 1903, he was appointed full
professor of German at the University of Marburg, which chair he
still occupies.
Dr. Elster has written many
notable works on German literature,
but his specialty is the poetry of
Heine. He is the greatest living
authority on this subject, and his
critical edition of Heine's poetical
works is immensely popular and
has already gone through five impressions. He is also editor of the
classical publications issued by the
Bibliographisches Institut, one of
the largest publishing houses in
Leipzig, famous as the city of
books. He has received numerous
honorary degrees, and is held in
high esteem by scholars the world
over. He has an elder brother who
is now filling an important post,
that of counsellor to the Minister
of Education.

Senator Attacks American Colleges.

United States Senator Hollis, in
a speech at the Harvard Union last
week, denounced the colleges and
universities of America as a "deadweight * * * around the necks
of the American people." In this
astonishing address, the Senator asserted that the professors were almost directly dependent upon the
rich men of the nation for their
support, and that, therefore, they
only taught the rich men's side of
the questions of the day.
Harvard was the particular object of the Hon. Hollis' wrath. He
called it "hide-bound and conservative," said that it was ruled by the
sons of the vulgar and idle rich,
and indirectly charged it with "eating from the hand that has robbed
the pockets of the people."
While this outburst was quite
evidently a play to the Massachusetts political gallery of those who
are instinctively against "highbrows," some of the things that the
speaker said are worth noticing.
Especially the reforms which he
suggests for Harvard are noteworthy. Among them he advocates
the refusal of large gifts from individuals, and the establishment of
a system by which future new
buildings will be paid for by the
alumni with contributions not exceeding a fixed sum.

The publication in last week's issue of the list of candidates out
for spring sports induced THE
NEws-LETTER's statistician to compile some percentages, with the result that a few very interesting
facts were discovered. During the
scholastic year of 1913-14, the student body has been composed of
267 undergraduates, distributed as
follows: candidates for the degree
of bachelor of arts, 17o; engineering department, 74, and special students, 12. Of these, 121 men have
come out for the four major sports
recognized by the Athletic Association. Last 'fall the football team
attracted 29 men, while at present
the lacrosse squad consists of 30
undergraduates,the baseball team of
22, and the track and field aggregation of the comparatively large
number of 40 men. This makes a
total of 121 out of 217 students
who at one time or another this
year have come out for athletics,
or an average of about 50 per cent.
of the entire undergraduate body.
These figures leave out of account
those who are out for the tennis
team, as well as medical men and
graduate students. These statistics
lead us to make the safe assumption that Hopkins easily leads all
other colleges in the percentage of
undergraduates indulging in officially recognized forms of sport..
This may be attributed to the small
size of the Hopkins student body,
but the fact remains that the undergraduates of this University are,
on the whole, loyal and brim full
of "college spirit." Alumni and
students fail to take these things
into, consideration when discussing
Hopkins athletics. It is the policy
of the Athletic Association to utilize, as far as possible, only undergraduates, as may be proved from
the fact that there are only five
medicos and graduates on the lacrosse squad and but three on the
track squad. Baseball claims the
largest number of the advanced
students, with two graduates and
ten medical men. When we remember that the undergraduate
department is the smallest in point
of numbers of the three great
branches of work at Hopkins, we
may feel proud of the way athletics
are regarded here.
College Athletics.

Some interesting data about college athletics have been given out
recently by the Research Committee
of the National Collegiate Association. The conclusion to be drawn
from the majority of the figures
and facts given, is that only rarely
does the whole student body take
part in any kind of organized athletics, and that enormous sums are
spent to condition a very few men
to represent their colleges in various lines of sport.

been before the Christian era.

blades were originally steel, but in
each case this metal has been almost completely destroyed by rust.

Dr. Ernest Elster, professor of
modern German philology and literature at the University of Marburg, will deliver a lecture in German on "Heine," next Wednesday
evening at 8.15 in McCoy Hall.
Dr. Elster was brought to this
country to give a brief course of
lectures at Cornell University, which
lasted until the past Friday. Leaving Ithaca, he struck through the
Middle West, where he is appearing at several universities before
coming to Hopkins. He will arrive
in Baltimore Wednesday morning,
and will spend the day at the Rennert. He will take luncheon with
Dr. and Mrs. Wood, who have invited the members of the Germanic
Seminary to meet their distinguished guest.
Dr. Elster was born in Frankfurt-on-Main, in 186o, and comes
from a family of well-known scholars. He received his secondary
education at such noted universities
as Berlin, Jena, and Leipzig, and
since his graduation has filled positions at Glasgow and Leipzig.
In 1903, he was appointed full
professor of German at the University of Marburg, which chair he
still occupies.
Dr. Elster has written many
notable works on German literature,
but his specialty is the poetry of
Heine. He is the greatest living
authority on this subject, and his
critical edition of Heine's poetical
works is immensely popular and
has already gone through five impressions. He is also editor of the
classical publications issued by the
Bibliographisches Institut, one of
the largest publishing houses in
Leipzig, famous as the city of
books. He has received numerous
honorary degrees, and is held in
high esteem by scholars the world
over. He has an elder brother who
is now filling an important post,
that of counsellor to the Minister
of Education.

The publication in last week's issue of the list of candidates out
for spring sports induced THE
NEws-LETTER's statistician to compile some percentages, with the result that a few very interesting
facts were discovered. During the
scholastic year of 1913-14, the student body has been composed of
267 undergraduates, distributed as
follows: candidates for the degree
of bachelor of arts, 17o; engineering department, 74, and special students, 12. Of these, 121 men have
come out for the four major sports
recognized by the Athletic Association. Last 'fall the football team
attracted 29 men, while at present
the lacrosse squad consists of 30
undergraduates,the baseball team of
22, and the track and field aggregation of the comparatively large
number of 40 men. This makes a
total of 121 out of 217 students
who at one time or another this
year have come out for athletics,
or an average of about 50 per cent.
of the entire undergraduate body.
These figures leave out of account
those who are out for the tennis
team, as well as medical men and
graduate students. These statistics
lead us to make the safe assumption that Hopkins easily leads all
other colleges in the percentage of
undergraduates indulging in officially recognized forms of sport..
This may be attributed to the small
size of the Hopkins student body,
but the fact remains that the undergraduates of this University are,
on the whole, loyal and brim full
of "college spirit." Alumni and
students fail to take these things
into, consideration when discussing
Hopkins athletics. It is the policy
of the Athletic Association to utilize, as far as possible, only undergraduates, as may be proved from
the fact that there are only five
medicos and graduates on the lacrosse squad and but three on the
track squad. Baseball claims the
largest number of the advanced
students, with two graduates and
ten medical men. When we remember that the undergraduate
department is the smallest in point
of numbers of the three great
branches of work at Hopkins, we
may feel proud of the way athletics
are regarded here.

from the majority of the figures
and facts given, is that only rarely
does the whole student body take
part in any kind of organized athletics, and that enormous sums are
spent to condition a very few men
to represent their colleges in various lines of sport.
